segments.text: By early 1967, it was well known that the state representative for the local legislative district made up of Brazos, Grimes, and Madison counties would not be a candidate for reelection.
He had moved out of the district and taken a job in Baytown, Texas.
Shortly after his announcement, my oldest brother began to discuss with me
the possibilities of my making the race for state representative.
I had never given any thought at all until he mentioned the possibility.
He began to explain to me the roles and duties of state representative, how much time it took, et cetera.
The more I thought about it, the more interested I became.
I had campaigned for my cousin in 1962
and had gotten a feel for what it was like to conduct a campaign back in those days.
I had not been able to increase my farm operation to the point that it occupied all of my time, so it did fit into the scheme of things for me to think about making the race.
One of the things that I wanted to do was stay on the
payroll at Texas A&M as long as I could because I needed the cash flow.
So I decided to not make an announcement until after the first of the year since when I did make an announcement, I would have to leave employment at Texas A&M.
I checked on the policy regulations of the A&M system and found that once you announced for a public office, you had to leave employment or resign your position.
So for that reason, I held off as long as I possibly could.
In the meantime, in November of that year,
a city councilman from Madisonville announced for state representative, and he was way ahead of any other announcements for the position.
I did feel a little pressure to let more and more people know that I planned to run, but I did not want to get out front too much simply because of the policy of the inning system.
In 1968, about mid-January, I resigned my position at A&M and made my announcement that I would be a candidate for state representative.
Shortly after making that announcement, I was visited in my office by a student who represented the Young Democrats.
He proceeded to interview me and ask a lot of questions, mainly regarding my political philosophy.
And shortly after he left, it wasn't too long until I had, there was another person joined the race, the president of the Texas A&M Young Democrats.
He would become the liberal in the race for state representatives.
A fourth candidate announced and filed just before the filing deadline.
He was a resident of Bryan and a chiropractor.
So we had a dairy farmer, myself, a city councilman from Madisonville, a young Democrat, and a chiropractor in the race for state representative.
We all ran as Democrats because there was very little activity in the Republican Party at that time.
In fact, as I recall, there were less than 200 votes cast that year in the Republican primary.
The only interest was in the statewide races, and therefore,
Few votes were cast in that particular primary.
Quite a change from what we have today.
One of the things I felt like I needed to do early was to establish a campaign office so that I had some visibility in the city of Bryan, which was the largest voting block in the district.
I was fortunate to locate a vacant office by a good friend, Dr. Howard Cargill, who was a veterinarian.
He had built a new office next door and vacated the space that I used as a campaign office.
This was on Texas Avenue and had great visibility between Bryan and College Station.
there in the main thoroughfare.
One of the things I did in the office early on was to play around with making some political science.
I tried to make them by hand but found out very quickly that that was not very productive.
In the meantime I learned a little bit about silk screening and got some friends together and we
made some 4x8 signs that were made with a silk screen.
At that time, no one had attempted to make sentinel signs, and no one had put up a 4x8 sign on vacant property.
But we found these to be quite effective, particularly since other candidates were not using them back in 1968.

I really didn't know how I was going to get my campaign started and what would be starting it, but fortunately I had a visit with a bank president and he told me that for the first time in history their bank, which was also the place where I banked, was going to get involved in politics.
They had decided to support me in my race, and this would be the first time that they had ever supported a candidate openly for any public office.
I was delighted because I knew the people and had a high regard for all of the officers in that particular bank.
One of the things that I suggested to the president is that I needed a
finance chairman and asked if his executive vice president could serve in that position.
He said it would be strictly up to him and I should ask him.
I did ask the executive vice president if he would be willing to serve and he said yes.
As soon as the word got out that he was serving as my finance chairman,
The competing bank and the largest bank in the bank was not happy at all and told me that I was making a big mistake and that I needed to find someone else to serve as my finance chairman.
I was concerned about this and didn't know which way to turn.
So I finally decided to go discuss it with the state senator at that time
lived in Brian and get his views.
He had been in the Senate for a long time and I felt like that at least give me some advice on explaining the situation to him.
He related a story to me about people that are person that had supported him that everyone said that he would be better off if he did not campaign for me.
But he said, I decided a long time ago that if somebody wanted to work for me, I was going to let them, regardless of their character or whatever.
I did not have a problem with the character of the individual.
He was certainly one of the most respected men in the town, and so that answered my question.
I went back and told the
person that he was still my finance chairman and that that was the end of any discussion with regards to replacing him as my finance chairman.
Early in the campaign I made two trips outside of my legislative district.
One was with my brother who lived in Austin.
and who took a day and went around to the offices of those executive directors of trade associations and some of the so-called lobbyists in Austin.
This was very productive.
They had a lot of contacts back in the district and traveled in and out of the district and had a good ear for what was going on and what might occur.
In fact, one of the lobbyists agreed to have a person on his staff come into the district and find out what the strategy might be of my opposition.
It developed from that swing through the district that the assessment of the race was that I was

probably the leading candidate in the race, and my principal opposition would be from the city councilman from Madisonville, who had good contacts into Brazos County and expected to carry the other two counties.
By that combination, I had a chance of winning the race.
Knowing this helped some because
I could plan some strategy and did not want to depend strictly upon Braggers County to win the race.
On the other hand, I felt like that Braggers County would be my strength, along with getting a significant vote out of Grimes County.
I did not expect to carry Grimes County, but I knew I had a lot of
friends who were in the dairy business in that county and thought I could depend on getting a rather significant vote there.
In the meantime, some very good things happened.
I had a friend who lived down the street who was in the labor movement and was able to help me not only try to neutralize the small labor movement that
that was in Brazos County but also had access to the minority community and was very helpful there in getting me in touch and giving me good recommendations with the minority leadership.
My father enjoyed campaigning and it turned out that he also knew a lot of
people in the minority community because of his background of running a country store where many of the minority families had been sharecroppers on the land that my grandfather owned.
Of course, these were children of those people that had sharecropped in many cases, but they still remembered coming to the store and
my father's kindness toward them.
I knew from the outset that the young Democrat candidate would be working the minorities very vigorously and would be expected to get a good vote.
But I also wanted to make a showing in that
community as well as carrying the vote on the other side of Texas.
I knew that Madison County had to be conceded to the local candidate who was a city councilman and very popular in that county.
The biggest surprise to many in the first primary was the vote that I got in Grimes County.
I carried the county along with Brazos County and liked only 67 votes winning over three candidates without a runoff.
This was a surprise to everyone as to the strength that I showed.
The runoff was a breeze with that kind of lead, but I decided not to take it for granted and continued
work for the next three weeks so that I would get a significant vote and margin in the runoff election.
This was the only time in my 15 years in the legislature and eight races that I had that I ever had to make a runoff.
This one was easy, but so many times runoffs are not much fun because it's hard to get people back out to the polls for the second time.
As near as I could determine, I spent about $3,500 on the race.
This was money that I didn't have with the exception of about $1,600 that I cashed out of my retirement at Texas A&M.
Most of the balance I was able to raise from small contributions locally through my finance chairman and some contributions
from the lobby in Austin.
I did come up $600 short for a bill that I owed in Austin to a printing shop.
And fortunately, some members of the lobby in Austin agreed to pick up the tab on that.
Back then, the finance laws for financing campaigns was much
more lenient and much more flexible than they are today.
It never occurred to me that I might have to go into debt during the campaign.
If I had thought about running up debt to make the race, I probably would have decided not to run.
Shortly after the runoff election, I decided that I would see if I could
go back to work at Texas A&M at least for a few months since I was no longer a candidate that had opposition.
I didn't know what the rules might be, but I contacted my cohort, who was the legislative person for the A&M system, and asked him what the rules might be.
He said he could find no reason why that I could not come back to work, particularly since my job position was still open and the office of the commandant.
I assumed my old position in office for about three days, and on the third day I got a call to come to the President Rutter's office.
I phoned visiting the President Rutter.
He suggested that
I moved to the budget office down the hallway from his office, and that he would like to switch me to a private payroll if that was okay with him, with me.
And I said that was certainly fine.
I had no problem with that at all.
This was a, turned out to be a fortunate happening.
because I was put on the payroll of the Texas A&M Research Foundation.
And years later, when I was working at the Research Foundation and subsequently resigned, I had just enough time to invest in their particular retirement program.
During that six-month period that I was down the hallway from President Rutter, I sat through the budget reviews
and in preparation for the legislative session and was certainly an education to me as to how the budget process works.
I also got a close-up of how President Rutter conducted himself as president of the institution and was quite impressed with
a person who showed great leadership ability.
And I think some of the traits that I found that he had made an impression upon me and hope that they help me in my decision-making later in my legislative years.
I'm sure that somewhere in the process that Mr. Rutter had also indicated to the Speaker of the House to me, Gus Mutcher, that it would be good if I served on the Appropriations Committee.
And President Rutter made it a point to suggest to me that I should ask for that committee.
I did ask for the committee and was one of the four freshmen appointed to the committee when the session convened in 1969.
January 1969 was a memorable experience as I joined the legislature and began serving as a freshman state representative.
Gus Mutcher of Brenham was elected without opposition as Speaker of the House.
Previous to his election, Ben Barnes had been Speaker, but had since been elected Lieutenant Governor and had moved over as Presiding Officer of the Texas Senate.
Governor Preston Smith was the new Governor.
So all three of the principals, Mutcher, Barnes, and Smith, were new in their jobs, just as I was.
I spent much of the session viewing budgets and reviewing budgets and trying to assist with the Texas A&M appropriations in any way that I could.
I found early that the process was quite different than you might expect.
The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee was a very strong individual.
He had a very strong personality and could be and had been described as a dictator.

I learned to appreciate the man over a period of years that I served with him and found that he was sometimes very difficult, but I suspect that he was this way to cover up a rather tender heart that he had underneath.
I carried a few bills that session, but did have two that was of interest to Texas A&M.
One of the things we were trying to do in Brazos County at the time was to find some land for industrial development and bring in some industry into the county.
Up until that time, we were very agriculturally oriented and
had a university that had a rather small enrollment at that time.
President Rutter had suggested that property at Bryan Air Force Base could be made available with the legislature's approval.
So we sought to get legislative approval for the transfer
exchange of property that was under the control of Texas A&M during the legislative session in 1969.
We were able to get legislation passed, but at the last minute the bill was amended to exempt the main campus.
The reason that was put in the bill was to avoid
any attempt through political pressure of a corporation building a hotel on the campus.
There was some discussion about a hotel being built on the campus and the Board of Regents of the Texas A&M University System did not want the pressure of making that decision.
The bill was amended to say that you have to come back to the legislature to get approval to build a building by private enterprise on the main campus.
Another problem at that time was to develop more of an airport facility than the county had.
The city of Bryan had a small airport, which was inadequate.
The primary facility was owned by Texas A&M University.
Texas A&M did not have the resources to develop the airport as it should be, so after looking at various possibilities and alternatives, I introduced a bill that would allow the county to create a
an airport authority and manage or control the airport at Eastwood, but be under the management of Texas A&M.
This would allow public funds to be funneled to the airport through the airport authority, which would have taxing authority.
The bill passed rather easily.
But when the election was held, it was defeated rather resoundingly.

The problem the bill had was that it provided that the airport authority could impose a tax of $0.50 on $100 evaluation, which was many times more money than would ever be required to operate an airport.
The bill has never been amended, but it's still on the books and does provide that possibility sometime in the future.
But because it lost so badly, when it was first initiated back in 1969, it has never been used as a vehicle to develop the airport facility here in Brazos County, which is still to this day
needed and could be a great boon to economic development.
There were a number of other issues that come to mind that were before the legislature in 1969.
One of the early votes taken was on creation of University of Texas at Dallas.
Until that time, that campus had been a private research institute, and the vote would make it a part of the University of Texas system.
I had been privately advised by a Dallasite that this was not a good concept and would end up costing the state considerably, and so I voted against it.
There were only 19 votes cast against the proposal, and I found out very quickly that the Dallas delegation could be pretty intimidating.
I never did know of them to carry out any threats, but there were certainly threats made after I cast that vote, even though it was overwhelmingly passed in the House.
Another bill that the speaker was particularly interested in passing was liquor by the drink.
And I had taken a position against liquor by the drink during the campaign in 1968 and was not about to change my position.
However, the pressure from the speaker can be rather significant.
But I found
later that we may have become good friends because of standing up to that pressure.
You never know.
I'm sure that at the time the vote was cast, he was delighted to have my vote.
But on the other hand, there are many times, as always true in the legislature and serving in the legislature, there's always a tomorrow.
And there were a lot of tomorrows in dealing with this speaker who I developed a rather good relationship with.
In a special session later that year, there was a bill to create a private insurance in lieu of the federal
Deposit Insurance Corporation, the FDIC.
This bill became known as one of the Sharkstown bills.
It passed without little opposition at the time and reached the governor's desk and was vetoed.
Even though the bill was vetoed, a great deal was made of the Sharkstown bills, a lot of
a little later, in fact, at the beginning of the next session, and created the Sharpstown scandal, which I will discuss later.
Another issue that occupied a great deal of my time in the interim was a proposal by a colleague to create a school of oceanography at the University of Houston.
I was not aware of this, but at that time, Texas A&M was producing almost 50% of all of the oceanography PhDs in the world.
And there was no undergraduate school of oceanography with the exception of one in the state of Washington in the entire nation.
The administration at Texas A&M felt like that it was not called for
and that it would be inappropriate to have a school of oceanography anywhere except at the graduate level.
And we were already turning out more than our share of oceanographers here at Texas A&M.
And the state did not need another school of oceanography anywhere.
It also turned out that the author of the bill was
close to my cousin who had run for lieutenant governor and had become a political influence in Parrish County even though he had been defeated.
And I recall his coming to Austin and telling the state representative in no uncertain terms that he was not to
push that bell, just let it drop.

He did let the bell drop but was interested in pursuing it during the interim and got an interim committee appointed and I got appointed as one of the committee members to study in more detail what was needed in the area of oceanography and marine studies.
This led to some very interesting trips that were made to
oceanographic institutes such as Scripps, Woods Hole, the University of Washington where they had the only undergraduate school of oceanography, and several other stops along the way.
I think that after the visits it became clear that we had no particular need for expanding the educational programs
in Texas with regards to oceanography, but did need to do something with the large to research along the coast.
This led to...
